talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Stott Despoja for her question. It is the first substantial question we have had from the opposition the whole afternoon. There is a fair amount of meat in the question, but at least it gives us food for thought. Senator Stott Despoja was referring to the fact that food commodities using gene technology have been in the marketplace overseas since 1992 and currently there are over 50 such commodities approved for food use worldwide. On 30 July 1998 health ministers, in their capacity as the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council, approved standard A18 to regulate the sale of foods produced using gene technology. This standard will come into effect nine months after the date of gazettal, on 13 May 1999. Senator Stott Despoja's question really should be asked after 13 May 1999 because the standard has not come into effect yet. Premising a question on the results after the standard comes into effect is not appropriate.

answer.para: Once the standard takes effect it will be illegal to send any food produced using gene technology unless it has been assessed as being safe by the Australia New Zealand Food Authority and approved by health ministers. The enforcement of the standard is the responsibility of state and territory health authorities. The pre-market approval requirement of the standard has been widely publicised in the media and in ANZFA publications, and the implications of the standard have been known by industry bodies and food companies in both Australia and New Zealand since the notification of a draft standard was announced in February 1997.

ANZFA has received six applications relating to foods derived from genetically modified crops, and public notification of these six applications was published on 28 October last year. ANZFA has completed the safety assessment of the first two of these six applications and has found that two commoditiesâone being herbicide tolerant soya bean and the other insect resistant cottonseedâmeet safety requirements for food. These two are the principal genetically modified food commodities that are currently in the marketplace in Australia and have been in use by manufacturers for several years. A recommendation to the Food Standards Council on the regulation of these commodities is expected in April. The council is then to decide whether to approve these foods for continued use in the food supply.

Being aware that many imported foods may not be covered by these six applications, ANZFA as a matter of urgency has notified food industry bodies, especially the owners of the original genetically modified commodity, in Australia, New Zealand and overseas of the need to submit applications for assessment. The minister is most concerned that, due to inaction on the part of the owners of these genetically modified commodities, many food importers and manufacturers in Australia and New Zealand may be damaged once the standard is enforced as of 13 May. If on 13 May, when the standard comes into force, ANZFA has before it applications that have yet to be fully assessed, health ministers will need to determine whether transitional arrangements are justified so as not to disrupt the marketplace.

talk.start.para: âI move:

I am sorry that the minister is about to leave the chamber. Minister, I cannot believe that, as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, you were unable in cabinet to ensure that what was recommended by the Constitutional Convention, in regard to a recognition of custodianship, would be included in the Prime Minister's preamble. I note that you indicated in your answer to Senator Faulkner that the preamble had been `put out for discussion'. That may be technically so but the Prime Minister has made it clear that this is a take it or leave it preambleâ`accept my preamble or forget it,' says the Prime Minister, quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 27 March, with the Prime Minister threatening to dump his preamble if the Senate prevented it being put to the people in November with the republic question. The report said:

Mr Howard again refused to countenance the preamble acknowledging the Aborigines' relationship to the land, guaranteeing it being blocked by the Senate in the face of unanimous opposition from Aborigines and Mr Howard's handpicked Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

But what about support for the preamble, not from the communityâwe know the talkback radio programs and the letters to the editor indicate that there is major embarrassment in regard to this preambleâbut from some of the Prime Minister's colleagues? The Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, said, `Yeah, I've read it. Any other questions?' Jeff Kennett is not somebody who usually goes quiet on subjects. He could not find any words to say about it. Similarly, Peter Costello said, `There it is. It's out there. People can have a look at it. People will have a free vote.' He is scarcely enthusiastic. Nor was the Attorney-General.

What about the National Party? At the Queensland conference at the weekend, angry National Party members slammed a `silly preamble'. The Queensland National Party conference was told yesterday that Prime Minister John Howard had hijacked coalition policy to produce his `silly preamble'. The National Central Council conference in Nambour has rejected the preamble, after an emotive debate signalling a renewed assault against the republic. Some conference delegates urged their party to reassert an uncompromising stand against constitutional change. A delegate of the Young Nationals accused Mr Howard of hijacking policy development. He said that, if we allow the Prime Minister to continue to dictate policy to us, we are abrogating our responsibility.

Quite clearly, this preamble is notâas it should beâa dialogue between the govern ment and the people of Australia. This is a dialogue between the Prime Minister and John Howard. He does not want to have any views other than his own recognised.

talk.start.para: âThat is why it is out for public discussion.

âWhy does he say, `Take it or leave it,' Senator? Mr Howard has dismissed criticism by the former ATSIC chairwoman, Dr O'Donohue, who has called his preamble `divisive'. Mr Howard said Aborigines would have to accept his proposal, Senator, or they will get no recognition at all in the Constitution.
âThat's right.

âI note that Senator Abetz is saying, `That's right'. This is a take it or leave it preamble. The complaints are pouring in. The federal sex discrimination office has been inundated with complaints from women about the Prime Minister's draft preamble, because of the use of the word `mateship'.
âHa, ha! See, you are either a hindranceâ

âThat is another joke! This government seems to have the strangest notions about what jokes are. First of all, we have the Aboriginal affairs minister thinking that a grossly insulting comment to Tiwi elders is a joke. Now we have Senator Abetz on the public record laughing and thinking that it is not acceptable for women to object to the term `mateship'. (Time expired)

âWe have just heard an interesting prattle on the preamble, raising this matter and that. But what we have not heard is what we now have in the preamble, in relation to reconciliation and indigenous people. We do not have a single word about reconciliationânot a mention of our indigenous people, not a mention of any of the patterns of migration that have taken place in this country over more than 200 years. We actually do not have a mention of indigenous people.
âYour party did not want to take note of Aboriginal people at all.

âWhat the government has done is release a draft preamble, Senator Schacht. It is very important that people see it in that light. But before we address the draft preamble, I would like to read into the Hansard some of the words that are actually in the existing preamble. When it was written in 1900, the intention was to give some information on the reason for the enactment of the legislation. Our intention in updating it is to more appropriately reflect why we want to continue to join together in what is actually a contract between the states and territories and its citizens. These are the sorts of words that are in the current preamble, which I think very effectively illustrate why the Prime Ministerâand indeed the entire governmentâwant to update this particular part of our Constitution. It includes such words as, in the third paragraph:

speech.para: Be it therefore enacted by the Queen's Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows . . .

I do not think that there is a person in this parliament or indeed in this country who would believe that those sorts of wordsâ`the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and Commons'âeffectively or appropriately anymore reflect the sorts of priorities that we have in this country or are an accurate reflection of the way that we are.

In my view, the government's draft preamble is not clumsy or awkward. It is more easily understood than what we have now. To me, it reflects more accurately our way of life and what has influenced us as we have matured as a nation. It expresses and reflects on our past, our future and on the important individual aspirations and freedoms that we hold for the future, in a way which enables each of us to interpret them as we wish.

Men and women who are around in times of trouble or sadness or celebration are people I call `mates'. They are my mates. I do not ring people up and say `mate', as some members of the Labor Party might do, and nor have I had any phone calls from people who might suggest that to me. But there is no doubt in my mind that the term `mateship' means, to me, a non-gender form of endearment.

When my father died, my mother told me that she had lost her best mate. I understood absolutely and very clearly what she meant. She did not mean it in any blokey way, nor did she expect that I would take it that way. I understood entirely what she meant. Some people want Australia to be remodelled as a republic to freshen our image overseas, to give us freedom and independence, but talking down this suggested preamble means that in the middle of next century we could still be arguing about itâespecially if we hear what Gareth Evans says: 30 years to codify the reserve powers of the Governor-General. At this rate, Gareth's select committee will still be considering this in 30 or 40 years time and there will still be no mention in our preamble of our indigenous families, no mention of those people who have come to this country over the last 200 years, no mention of anything that more appropriately reflects the kind of country we now are. We will simply have, if Gareth has his way, `Lords Temporal and Spiritual' and other inappropriate forms of words. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAfter the contribution from Senator Ferris, one realises how bad this preamble that the Prime Minister inflicted on the Australian people last week really is. If the best defence the Prime Minister can get is for Senator Ferris to make remarks such as, `It is better than what was written 100 years ago' as if that is the only benchmark, that is extraordinary. To say that the definition is based on her mother's description of her relationship with her fatherâ
âDon't be offensive, Senator.

âI am just stating what you said. We have had an extraordinary performance from the Prime Minister. As I said before lunch in the debate about the Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 , the Prime Minister discovered that, come the referendum to decide whether Australians should have one of their own as president, he would be one of the few people out there saying no and he would look an utter dill in being so. He had to think of something he could positively put up and say, `I am in favour of it. Yes.' So he came up with the preambleânot the preamble that the Constitutional Convention proposed 14 months ago after at least two weeks of discussion among a cross-section of all political thought ranging across the community. No, we do not have that preamble; John Howard says, `I'm not a bad hand with a pen. I'll have a go at it.' He spoke to two people: Les Murray and Professor Blainey are the only two he consulted. He did not consult Robert Hill. He did not consult Senator Ferris or Senator Abetzânot one member of the parliamentary Liberal Party was consulted. They all had to have amnesia. Then he put it to them at the party meeting, saying `This is the wonderful document' and daring anyone to say no. They all rolled over and said, `Yes, it's fine.' Then they started leaking to the press this week what a dumdum the Prime Minister is and what a stupid preamble it is.

speech.para: In particular there is the issue of his prejudicial view in not recognising the prior custodianship of Aboriginal people on this continent. We have this phrase `since time immemorial'. What does that mean? From when does `immemorial' begin?

talk.start.para: âSince recorded history.
âAboriginal people do have recorded history, you dope.
âThey do not have recorded history.

âI beg your pardon? He says they do not have recorded history. All of the rock paintings going back tens of thousands of years are not recorded history? Of course, Senator Abetz's view of recorded history is what has been written in a law book printed in the last 30 years. That is his idea of recorded history. This is another example of the Liberal Party being so out of tune. A majority of Australian people are quite willing to say it is quite reasonable to have a preamble that states the fact that the Aboriginal people were here before white settlement; that they had custodianship of this land and that should be recognised.

speech.para: Because of his prejudicial and 1950s view of how the world should be and how in particular Australia should be, the Prime Minister has written a preamble that does nothing else but reflect his view that Australia in the next century should be based on when he thought Australia was at its bestâthe 1950s. It is a disgrace that he proposes this to the people. No wonder he is being derided all around Australiaâlaughed at by half of the Liberal Party. Even one of the most conservative figures, Bruce Ruxton, has dismissed it as pure corn. Others well noted for their conservative views have laughed it off the stage. The best thing this Prime Minister could do, as I said earlier, is take the view of Sir Robert Menzies when he tried to propose the name `royal' for our decimal currency amid great derision: he withdrew it. The Prime Minister should withdraw his preamble and allow a proper consultation within the Australian community about what would be a decent preamble for all of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat we have seen is a hysterical and affected opposition by Senator Reynolds and the Labor Party to a preamble. What Senator Schacht and those on the other side cannot overcome is the fact that they had 13 years in government to deal with this very sensitive issue. Did they ever once come up with a proposal for the Australian people? No, there was absolutely none, because they were too scared or incapable of dealing with such an important decision, with such an important provision for our Constitution. Senator Ferris has just told the Australian people what the preamble actually says at the moment. After having dealt with Labor's economic mess in our first term of government, we are now turning ourselves to some of the other social issues which are of importance to this nation. As a result, early on in this our second term, we are dealing with the issue of the preamble.

speech.para: Let us have a look at the draft for a national declaration of reconciliation forwarded by the chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Evelyn Scott, on 17 March 1999. Paragraph 2 states:

We celebrate the fact that the Aboriginal culture is the oldest living continuous culture on the planet. That culture is still alive. It is sacred, spiritual and practical, a unique way of living in harmony with the land. Through the land and its first peoples, newcomers to this country may taste that spirituality and rejoice in its grandeur.
In the draft preamble to the Constitution, the Prime Minister suggests:
Since time immemorialâ
or oldest living continuous culture, according to the draft for a national declaration of reconciliation, which is very similar wordingâ
our land has been inhabited by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who are honoured for their ancient and continuing cultures.

It is virtually identical to what Evelyn Scott and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation have put forward. Yet there is this affected hysteria from those on the other side who are trying to suggest that the preamble does not do the right thing by our fellow Australians who are our indigenous brothers and sisters. The reality is that that is exactly what the draft preamble is doing.

I suggest to honourable senators opposite that they take a broad view of the Australian population and ask themselves if they want to frame a preamble in the politically correct manner that Kim Beazley suggests, falling over himself to put wheelbarrow load after wheelbarrow load of political correctness before the Australian people. You can bet your bottom dollar that especially in the blue ribbon Labor seats that preamble would be rejected. The Prime Minister is seeking to chart a course not for political correctness but for what the Australian people, as a whole, will reasonably adopt, accept and incorporate into their Constitution to make it a more living document, to make it more representative of the aspirations of the Australian people, as our country exists today.

Indeed, the preamble goes on to talk about the enrichment to this nation provided by migrants. There are a lot of other excellent comments in this preambleâindeed, statementsâwhich enrich our constitutional structure. It will be a great document for all Australians to read and consider when they think about what being Australian means. I suggest to my friends opposite that they stop and think for a while. The next election is not going to be won or lost over the preamble issue, so take a statesmanlike approach to this sensitive issue and, for a change, don't be negative, look at it in a positive light and make a positive contribution to your country, and remember that for 13 years you had the opportunity and failed to deliver one word of preamble. talk.start.para: âI rise to take note of the answer given by Senator Herron to Senator Faulkner on the preamble on behalf of the many constituents who have phoned my home and my office in the last few weeks. The statement read as followsâ
In all, this report considers eight treaties covering a wide range of subjects, including:
. the destruction of anti-personnel mines;
. the Bougainville peace monitoring group; and
. economic cooperation with Indonesia.
In each case the committee has concluded that it is in Australia's national interest to ratify the proposed treaties.
In the time available to me, I will comment briefly on the major elements of the report.

The Treaties Committee is strongly supportive of the Convention on the Prohibition and Destruction of Anti-personnel Mines. The Convention is an historic step towards the aim of a total global ban on anti-personal mines. The Australian Government's commitment to the Convention is to be applauded. As is the passage, by this parliament, of the Anti-personnel Mines Convention Act 1998âwhich implements in Australian law the obligations imposed by the Convention.
Our report makes two recommendations aimed at continuing the momentum towards a global ban on anti-personnel mines:

. first, that the Minister for Defence formulate principles to guide the retention of mines for defence training purposes, so as to clarify the process and timeframe for the destruction of those mines not required for training purposes; and

. second, that, in appropriate international fora, the Australian Government put a strong position against the development of replacement weapons technologies which have indiscriminate and inhumane effects similar to those possessed by anti-personnel mines.
The committee also strongly supports the Bougainville Peace Monitoring Group Protocol.
Australia has played a significant role in the Bougainville peace process:
. by facilitating truce and ceasefire discussions between the warring parties;
. by contributing around 250 civilian and unarmed Defence Force personnel to the work of the Peace Monitoring Group; and
. by sponsoring a substantial and growing aid program.

Given the scale and nature of the devastation caused by the conflict, there is much work to be done to restore even the most basic community services to those living on Bougainville. Australia's aid program will continue to play a crucial role in re-establishing services and infrastructure; in building new systems of administration; and in restoring a functioning economy.
The third major treaty considered in Report 20 is the Development Cooperation Agreement with Indonesia.

This Agreement is intended to provide a generic legal framework for Australia's development cooperation program with Indonesia. It is a usefully document, which will simplify the project development processes for both governments and for the non-government organisations commissioned to run aid projects in Indonesia.

The Agreement is important not only for what it provides, but because it signals that, at a time of great social and political upheaval in Indonesia, Australia is committed to building structures to support a continuing and cooperative relationship with one of its nearest neighbours.
I would finally like to refer to the proposed Amendment to the Health Services Agreement with the United Kingdom.

While we support the amendment, and acknowledge that reciprocal medical treatment agreements are of considerable benefit to Australians travelling overseas, we are concerned about the adequacy of the costing information upon which such agreements are based. In this, as in previous cases, we were not provided with sufficient information to assess whether both parties to the agreement would be exposed to similar costs.

We have recommended that, when negotiating such agreements in future, the Department of Health and Aged Care undertake a more rigorous assessment of the likely costs, to both parties, of the agreement.
In conclusion, I thank all those who have contributed our reviews. These contributions are important and help promote greater transparency in the treaty-making process.
I commend the report to the Senate.

âI want to acknowledge first of all the extraordinarily high quality of the submissions made to this inquiry and to put on the record my thanks to all of those for the time and effort put into submissions and presentations. The arguments and the evidence overwhelmingly demonstrated that the government's tax package would be extremely harmful to the health of our environment and to the health of our cities. This report is a very well documented account of the negative effect of the government's new tax package over these wide-ranging fields.

speech.para: What has been absolutely clear to the committee is the fact that the government has missed a rare opportunity to reform the tax system in a way that has positive outcomes for the environment and the arts. Australia is one of the few countries in the OECD which has not implemented ecological tax reform and, rarer still, in proposing to significantly reduce the price of fuel. Witnesses pointed out that not only was Australia proceeding along a path which would seriously worsen our air pollution problems but also vehicles were currently only required to comply with emission standards which are at least five years behind those of Europe and the US.

The committee's attention was drawn to Australia's international obligations on greenhouse gas emissions. This tax package sends a powerful message to the international community that Australia does not consider greenhouse issues to be of central importance to the nation's future or, for that matter, to the world's. It has been difficult to cast any sort of positive light on the policy objectives which must have informed this tax reform package. Central to the deliberations of the committee were whether benefits to farmers and business could be delivered in a more environmentally responsible way, and I believe the recommendations do just that.

It appears that the package was prepared in isolation by Treasury and that neither Environment Australia, the Greenhouse Office nor the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts were consulted by Treasury. Neither were the many submitters with expertise in the field.

The diesel fuel currently imported to Australia has high levels of sulfur which results in a much higher level of particle emissions than do gaseous fuels. Medical evidence linking particulates from diesel engines with conditions like asthma translate into health and social costs which some estimate to be as high as $2 billion per year. There is sufficient evidence on the health impacts of diesel fuels to suggest that even the current level of diesel use should be lowered and powerful incentives and standards introduced to accelerate Australia's progress towards cleaner engines and diesel fuel with much lower sulfur content. The committee heard that it was likely that old polluting diesel vehicles would be dumped into Australia unless our standards were brought into line with Europe and the US.

Our present tax system does not impose an excise on gaseous fuels, and this provides some incentive to changing over from petrol and diesel to LPG and CNG. This industry would collapse under the new tax package. When the New Zealand government removed the price differential between gas and diesel there was a dramatic reduction in the use of gaseous fuels. Already, decisions are being made by bus operators in Sydney, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide and Geelong to pull back from converting from diesel to gas. Heavy transport engines are now available which can run either dedicated CNG or with dual fuel options. This package would discourage any move towards the use of these vehicles.

The massive reduction in diesel will bring about a very significant increase in road transport at the expense of rail with very serious consequences. A GST on public transport means that bus and rail will become more expensive relative to private transport. Solar hot-water services would rise in price by around four per cent relative to the price of similar gas or electricity hot-water systems. The world leadership that Australia currently has in solar electricity development and the potential for the industry to generate revenue in excess of $1 billion every year is also at risk.

The reduction in diesel fuel excise would bankrupt the oil recycling industry, leaving around 150 million litres of lubricating oil being dumped rather than recycled. In the view of the Democrats, the $3.5 billion in petrol and diesel tax cuts should be significantly reduced, and measures should be introduced to see that the remaining cuts are targeted to reduce transport costs for rural producers and are properly tailored to deliver better ecological practices.

It is the Democrats' recommendation to amend the tax package to: continue to tax petrol and diesel through the excise system rather than the GST; maintain the current 100 per cent diesel rebate for all agricultural and other fully rebateable off-road uses; cap the rebate for mining and other use at the current level and provide a pro rata amount for all off-road use, bringing in line industries such as tourism; provide rail with a 100 per cent diesel rebate, recognising that rail, too, is an off-road use; provide a tightly targeted rebate for heavy road transport by increasing the weight threshold from 3.5 to 20 tonnes; require companies claiming the rebate to progressively reduce fuel emissions; apply an additional sales tax to new motor vehicles with low fuel efficiency, based on a sliding scale; zero rate public transport; introduce a range of non-tax related measures to reduce pollution and other greenhouse gas emissions; and other measures to improve the viability of the gaseous fuel industry through exemptions and capital grants.

The Democrats recognise the important contribution the arts make to our cultural identity, and we also recognise the financial vulnerability of many arts organisations and artists. I think there is little doubt that the arts sector will be damaged by this package. The performing arts groups are already experiencing severe losses, and the incomes of individual artists are already amongst the lowest of any working group.

I would like to finish by saying that the preparation of this report has stretched the resources of the committee secretariat to the limit. I want to sincerely thank Mr Richard Selth, Mr Ross Kilmurray, Mr Jason Vickery and Mr Tony Burke for an excellent report and for their patience and willingness to work long hours to have it tabledânot just in time but two days earlier than the due date. The secretariat had to meet very tight timelines for this inquiry whilst also conducting hearings into the government's new Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill, which were held in each capital city.
I commend this report to the Senate and hope the government can see their way clear to making urgent changes to their tax package as a result of such overwhelming evidence.

talk.start.para: âThis is the first report in a series of four on the GST. I would like to make some general comments before I get into some of the specific issues of what we are reporting on today.

speech.para: We went to the last election totally up-front about a GST package. We said precisely what we are going to do in terms of collection of this tax and the way in which we are going to compensate people for that tax increase. We had a very wide-ranging set of measures in terms of income tax cuts and increased welfare benefits to offset that.

The Australian people, in October last year, gave their verdict. We went to the election with this tax package as the central issue, and we were re-elected. What we have in the Senate is, again, obstruction of the government program. We had the setting up of a series of inquiriesânot one but four. After the time it has taken, and the amount of travel, to collect evidence around Australia, what do we end up with at the end of the day? We have a report and at the end of that report the Australian Democrats have added their view; the Greens have taken a slightly different view; the Labor Party has a different view again; and the coalition has a different view again. That is exactly what we went into the last election on, and here we are, after all this process, all this time and all this cost, with precisely the same outcome again. What a waste of time it has all been.

There are none so blind as those who will not see, and that applied in this set of hearings. We had interest groups come along and provide us with evidence, all based on price increases with the GST, and I do not recall one ever taking into account the fact that we had a compensation package. In areas like the arts they were talking about changes in the price of tickets. They took absolutely no account of the fact that there were also changes in compensation through income tax changes and increased welfare benefits. They also totally ignored the fact that we are in a time of rising real income and incredibly low inflation and the fact that the arts industries have thrived over the last 20 years in times of very high inflation. We now have low inflation, rising real incomes and a compensation package for people who want to attend arts functions. To claim there is going to be some great crash in the arts as a result of this is absolute nonsense. As a matter of fact, I found a lot of the languageâparticularly in the recommendations from the ALPâextremist in nature, because a lot of the evidence showed that any effect was going to be very minor and there was sufficient compensation in most cases.

I would like to turn to the main point of the report, which dealt with the effect on the environment. The emphasis here was very much on fuelsâon the way in which use of diesel fuel would change as a result of this tax. It defies the imagination to think that anyone, because there are lower prices of fuel, will suddenly start driving around a lot more and burning up that fuel. To back that up, I would like to quote from a news release from the National Farmers Federation. The news release states:

"Are the AMA and the ACF seriously suggesting that farmers will spend more time and more money than they need to harvest grain or plant crops, that truck drivers will take the long way round between Sydney and Melbourne, or that passenger vehicle drivers in our major cities will choose to spend more time in traffic, just because the cost of diesel is reduced!", Mr Donges said.

I think this points out the absurdity of the proposition. Where is this big increase in fuel use going to come from? Some have claimed there will be an intermodal shift between road and rail. The evidence from the Road Transport Forum tended to show that this would be, if anything, quite minor; that the shift to suddenly transporting goods by road instead of rail would be quite tiny indeed.

The thing that it totally lacks is in the context of what is happening with technology. Because of the emissions standards in Europe and the United States, there is now a major shift towards compressed gas technology in big engines such as those that drive trucks and buses. That will dramatically reduce greenhouse gases from road transport, despite anything else that is happening. So all the claims and all the evidence about terrible health outcomes from this were totally exaggerated as well.

I suggest people look at the evidence from the Road Transport Forum. I suggest people look at the evidence from Environment Australia, particularly from Dr Beale, which shows that the positions of the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats are a gross overstatement of effect. Yet again, as they did in the election campaign, they are trying to scare people on some things that are not major concerns but are minor concerns. They totally ignore counterbalancing measures: in the case of transport, with new technology; in the case of the arts, with compensating money that is coming from the tax package. The people of Australia should be very aware of how these opposition parties are trying to dupe them on these matters. If we are to have a fully competitive economy that is international best practice, this country must move to have a reformed tax system. The GST package that we went to the election honestly on is the one that should be adopted in this country.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak to this report. At the outset, I commend the secretariat and other members of the committee for their arduous application to this inquiry and also to the other concurrent inquiry in respect of environment legislation, which has still not been completed. The committee has had a lot of work to do, and they should be commended for the way they have done it.

speech.para: This was an extremely useful inquiry. The inquiry went across the country, and it went across sectors that will be affected by the GST package. This inquiry in a sense did the job the government was not prepared to do. We consulted and we met with people. We listened to industry concerns, and we met with environmentalists and specialists. It has to be said, at the end of the day, that the overwhelming evidenceâif not the total evidenceâthat the committee heard expressed concerns as to the government's processes and policies. We found no consultations. We found no consideration of some quite critical issues. We found total disregard for the concerns of those who have concerns for the environment, for the arts industry, for the books industry and particularly for new emerging technological industriesâexport industries that will be very negatively affected by the government's proposals.

It has to be said that all but the government senators have agreed on the flaws in the GST package and, as I said, there are quite a few of them. Not a voice was put to us in support of the government's proposals. Many voices were put to us in opposition. Many voices were concerned because of negative impacts on the arts industries, on literacy levels and particularly on the environment. The flaws are many. The major flaw is that the government in no way considered the impacts of its packageâfor instance, on the environment. The only process that has been embarked upon by the government to consider the environmental aspects of this package, which has been years in the making, has been commissioned by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage in recent daysâlong after the event. He started the process of commissioning it last November after the election, but it has only been in the last few days that a consultant has been given the job to do the work.

We are concerned because we see that the GST package is fundamentally flawed when it comes to environmental issues and to some pretty critical industries in the Australian community. The evidence before the committee was that the GST package would have a negative impact on all areas examined by the committee, including: the environment, especially in urban areas; public transport services; emerging technologies; exports; the arts, including books and literature; non-profit organisations; and information technology and communications.

One sector that spoke very strongly and with deep concern as to the impact of the GST on its business was the rail sector. If people anticipate that the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line will be completed under current funding arrangements, then they have something coming to them. If people think that the Melbourne to Darwin line will be completed under the funding arrangements announced by the Prime Minister, then they have something coming to them as well. This particular tax proposal sounds the death knell for those two railway lines unless the government is prepared to increase subsidies towards them. Why is this so? Because the impact of the government's fuel tax changes will mean greater reliance on and greater use of road transport as opposed to rail transport. That was a concern put to us not just by Australian Rail but by Queensland Rail and by a number of independent commentators as well.

The impacts on the environment are manifold. The government will in no way be able to meet its commitments to Kyoto greenhouse gas reduction targets. It will in no way be able to meet commitments to urban Australia in terms of environmental clean-up and the quality of air in our crowded suburbs. This is evidence that came to us across the spectrum. The natural gas industry came to the committee saying, `There are two things: first of all, we haven't been consulted; secondly, contracts that we expected for the use of natural gas vehicles and contracts to supply buses in New South Wales and other states are now under a cloud because of the economics of the GST package, which make the use of natural gas less productive and less profitable than other fuels.' Those sectors need to be considered, and they are a major concern as well.

This is a package which, at the end of the day, also fails in terms of the compensation aspects. When you talk to the arts industry, the Autogas Committee of Australiaâas we didâand to those involved in waste oil collection you can see that not only are they going to be negatively affected but also the compensation package which the government is touting across the country will in no way meet their concerns.
Michael Lynch of the Sydney Opera House, for instance, expressed the concerns expressed by many when he said:
My concerns are . . . with both the major organisationsâ
including hisâ

their stress point and the reason they have called an inquiry into them and the small organisations. The range of changes and the range of compliance issues they will need to deal with . . . are going to be extraordinarily onerous
I took notice of the comments about the small business package, but from my point of view a lot of small businesses in Australia are going to be going for that $500 million.

That $500 million will not hit first base when it comes to the impacts on the industries that this committee was concerned about. As I say, going back to the primary focus of this committee's deliberations, all the evidence before the committee points to disastrous and long-term damage to the environment.

talk.start.para: âNonsense.

âSenator Tierney, you are not blind, but you refuse to see. The evidence is that there will be an increase in diesel fuel pollutants and greenhouse gases and a reduction in economic incentives to use alternative, environmentally friendly fuels and technologies. If you think it is nonsense, you go back to those industries. You did not have enough guts to say to them face to face that they were talking nonsense; you shirked away from that. You go to those industries and say, `Look, you're telling us you are going to go bankrupt, but it is all nonsense.' It is not your job that is at risk; it is theirs.
âThe Greens would like to share this seven minutes between them. I have followed as much as I could of this committee, including getting abuse at times from Senator Tierneyâ
âIt's good to see you here today.
âAs I said, I followed as much as I could, including getting abused by Senator Tierney when he did not actually turn up to the Perth one either.
âOne. How many did you go to?

âI would like to put on record that, having attended the committee hearings via a telephone link from Perth, my staff member and I got up at about five o'clock in the morning on a public holiday to listen to the evidence of this committee.

speech.para: Senator Tierney interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe reality is that Senator Tierney has got up here and tried to diminish, demean and devalue the vast evidence given by community groups, environment groups, medical groups, arts groups all around Australiaâthis is why I am angry. He did not like what he heard. The coalition did not like it because these are issues of which the best interpretation is that they are an unintended consequence of this package. When the full Senate select committee looked at these issues on some small aspects relating to the mining industry, yes, the Liberal senators were impressed. Yes, they looked at each other, nodded wisely and said, `Ooh! Unintended consequence. Let us look at these and make sure we can make changes.' But when it is about the environment, about whether or not we are going to encourage people to make changes towards purchasing diesel rather than gasâyou would have to be blind not to see the advertisements already in the media for new gas vehicles, for new diesel technology. The diesel distributors, the people who import diesel and diesel technology, cannot believe their luck. It is not going to affect most of the people in rural communities. The impact is mostly going to be on the urban environment, on our health, our future and our greenhouse gas emissions.

speech.para: We also need to look at the impact on the community. When it comes to business costs, yes, the coalition are impressed. But when it comes to community costs it is, `Gosh, who are they? Why are they important? Oh gosh, let us think about the business community and the private sector.' But when it is the community, then it is, `No, you can get over it;' the arts, `Hey, you can live.' The reality is that when real impacts on real people are mentioned, the coalition turn their backs.

The Greens (WA) and the Australian Greens have put together some recommendations. We have agreed with the general concepts produced by the main committee report, but we have also made some specific recommendations. I commend those recommendations to honourable senators. They include that the proposed reduction in all fuel excises be abandoned and the acknowledgment of the extensive short- and long-term health, environment and economic costs. They look at making sure the government actually do their homework, which they did not do, and calculate the whole range of economic, environment and social costs and that they explore less environmental and health destructive ways of assisting the rural communities.

We should be looking at further policy options to ameliorate immense negative impacts on the cultural industries and also at an extension of the inadequate $500 million package to small businesses, community and charity organisations, because it will not go far in the analysis. I shall leave the rest of this presentation to my colleague Senator Brown.

talk.start.para: âWhat an indictment of the government policy against the interests of Australia this matter is.
âYou should have come to the hearings.

âMr Acting Deputy President, despite the braying interjections opposite, this is a serious matter. What we have here is a policy which is going to seriously damage Australia's environment. It is a policy which is going to cut across Australia's obligations to the international community and to future generations. The GST, as the committee has discovered, is a recipe for spewing carcinogens into our most populous areas, with consequent horrendous results, both human and economic, down the line. The GST package is a recipe for boosting the production of greenhouse gases in this country at a time when we need to be cutting back. The GST is even a recipe for getting our forests to the wharves $1 a tonne cheaper so that the woodchippers can continue the rape and destruction of one of this nation's most desired assets.

speech.para: Not only does the GST package not help poorer people, but when it comes to the environmental aspects it also actually materially degrades the living environment for all Australians in the future, be they poor or rich. It is a failure of government policy because when you are bringing in a comprehensive tax change you have to look at the ramifications for the community right across the board and into the future. The GST package is not only anti-environment, it compounds the problem of fixing environmental taxes into the system so that we can catch up in the future with Scandinavia and other countries by taxing polluters and giving incentives to those who do the right thing by the environment.

I would say to our friends in the Democrats: we warned about this before the last election. Nothing has changed. The information has come in to endorse what the Greens said last year. This package is an environmental horror. It goes against the interests of this country and future generations. It is one more good reason why, when the GST package comes into this place, it should be voted down. It is time for the Democrats to change tack and to say they will not accept a package which has such an environmental impost buried in it. (Time expired)

speech.para: Leave granted.
The report read as followsâ
Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill 1998
Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Charges Bill 1998

On Wednesday 24 March 1999, the Senate Selection of Bills Committee tabled its 4th Report of 1999, recommending that the above two bills be referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report. The proposed date of a public hearing was Friday 26 March, and the proposed date of a report was Monday 29th March. The Committee did not proceed with a hearing on 26 March. It is now tabling an interim report in order to meet the requirement to report on 29 March.

The Committee met briefly on 25 March to note the reference and to determine available dates to hold public hearings. It also agreed to make an interim report, rather than simply request an extension of time, in order to note two linked issues: the process of referring bills and the other commitments of Committees.

The Committee believes it is important for the selection of bills committee to ensure that all potential references are advised to Committee chairs in order for advice to be given about possible reporting dates.

The Committee also believes it is important for proposed dates of hearings and reports to be examined before being accepted. Even if the Legal and Constitutional Committee had no other work, it would have been impossible for it to contact all twenty three proposed witnesses, obtain submissions, advise the departments concerned, determine who would give evidence, and hold a hearing within such a limited timeframe. Other resources are also required such as Hansard services.

To write a report based on a hearing called at such short notice would also be difficult, because any additional comments or dissenting report could only be drafted after the Chair's draft was ready. This would require all involved staff to work all weekend. It would also mean that Hansard would be under pressure to provide a transcript, also over the weekend. It is sometimes necessary to provide reports under these circumstances, but no reason has been given why this would be necessary in this instance.

The Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee is currently examining three migration bills and finalising a report on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Bill 1998. This last bill is of considerable significance and the Committee has given it priority so that a report can be tabled this week. This has meant that committee members have been involved in writing comments during the last week and over the past weekend, and the Committee Secretariat was not in a position to take on additional work for this new reference.

It is also worth noting that such short reporting deadlines do not inspire confidence in the fairness of Senate processes. Some of the organisations that wish to give evidence have stated that they were also surprised at the short time recommended, and would be pleased to see more time devoted to the matter.

The Committee respectfully requests that the Senate, through the Selection of Bills Committee, reconsider the suggested hearing and reporting dates, and do so in consultation with the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.
Suggested Dates

Given other commitments, the Committee suggests that any hearings be held during the week beginning 12 April 1999, and the report be tabled on 19 April 1999. This allows time for submissions to be made and for appropriate consideration of the issues, even though there is limited time for the production of a transcript.

talk.start.para: âWhen we were last considering this bill before question time today, the minister's response was fairly limited or scratchy, from my point of view, in relation to why the government was actually spending more on what in effect was the no case. The question is: has a decision been taken to fund a no case on the preamble?
