talk.start.para: âI appreciate the opportunity to speak tonight. I intend to devote the few minutes available to me to the coalition government's Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 . That bill introduces voluntary student unionism to the Australian universities, less those in Western Australiaâthe progressive stateâwhich has had voluntary student unionism for about five years. The Western Australian legislation was passed during the time that I was still serving in the state Legislative Council. There are several major myths associated with the fear of bringing in democratically proposed voluntary unionism. Part of those myths can be dispelled, if not all of them.

speech.para: I am not in the habit of publicising the Australian Democrats, a political party for which I do not have much time at all, let alone agreeing with what they say. But when the Australian Democrats' higher education principles were released, I found there was some common ground that I had with them. I do not know whether that is an indictment of me or whether the Australian Democrats are becoming more democratic in their old age.

They have a pledge to decrease student fees and charges. They have a pledge to enhance access to higher education. They also have a belief that students must be able to control their own affairs. They support the incubus of compulsory student unionism, however, which is contradictory to those beliefs.

I can only come to the conclusion that they do not really mean it. If those three points were introduced, do they agree with some universities introducing and following through on the idea that degrees will not be granted unless student fees with respect to their guilds are paid? What VSU does is reduce barriers to higher education. It removes a compulsory up-front fee. It does not necessarily remove fees but it removes the compulsion to pay fees. It gives students freedom of choice to control their own affairs. That is not a bad start to democracy in tertiary education. And it puts power back into the hands of the students. It gives them the taste of power for their future lives. It recognises that students are sensible, intelligent and responsible enough to decide for themselves in a democratic process how their money is to be spent. What we don't say is that student unions, or any other union in Australia, should be outlawed. What we do say, however, is that if students want to join a union they can. We are not saying: do without unions. We don't say that in the work force. We don't say that either in the Western Australian legislation. But we do say that in this enlightened world students should have a choice as to whether they join a union or not.

I understand what the reason is behind compulsory unionism in tertiary institutions. It gives the socialistsâthat is, the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democratsâwho want to inculcate a culture of compulsion in unions the start to put that in the minds of tertiary students. In some cases this carries on, of course, throughout their adult life. What that does is give the Bill Keltys, Bob Hawkes and Paul Keatings of this world a great advantage, and that is the culture of compulsory unionismâno ticket, no start. That is not what a modern world is about; that is not what Australia is about.

Let me draw a distinction between the legislation passed under the Victorian model, which used the term `voluntary student representation', or VSR, and the voluntary student unionism of Western Australia: a model which the coalition government's legislation superimposes from Western Australia, where it has been in now for five years. The Victorian model draws an artificial distinction between essential services and non-essential services. Under VSR, the Victorian model, a compulsory fee is still collected to fund those activities deemed non-political. We do not think that is good enough. Who is to decide what is political and what is non-political? We want students throughout Australia to decide for themselves whether or not they join a union with respect to their tertiary education.

Myth 2 is that, under the VSU, organisations and services will cease to exist. That is the big bogy. Of course, it does not happen. Let me have a look at some of the things at UWA. Voluntary unionism is five years old there. Cards are still available at Steve's Nedlands Park Hotel. You get a bar discount, you get a Steve's cafe discount and you get a bottle shop discount. The Grosvenor Hotel has discounts and the Metropolis Hotel has discounts. It goes on. There is a whole list of discounts that the student guild still runs. There are nightclub discounts. To change tack, the guild sells discounted clothing and merchandise. The guild runs a copy centre. The guild runs a second-hand bookshop. It sells cards, gifts and stationery. It runs a University of Western Australia tavern. It runs a guild market. It provides Hostelling International membership. It runs dry-cleaning. It runs Talking Heads hair design. It runs a campus pharmacy and eye-care centres. It runs a travel agency. It even runs American Express at a discount. It runs boat trips to Rottnest Island at a discount. It has got live jazz in Cafe Acorn. It has got Winthrop Australia, which is a computer shop that the guild also runs. Don't tell me that services have dropped off.

Okay, you say, that is UWA, which is a fairly distinctive, perhaps top end of the street university and is one of the best universities in Australia. But look at the Student Guild at Curtin that everyone said would collapse. It has membership benefits. It has student assistance with respect to making life at university better. It offers campus services, clubs and activities, housing and the Guild Council. It connects with overseas student bodies. It has the Curtin Postgraduate Association. It runs a bookshop and it runs a paperâall funded by the voluntary contributions of students. It offers bookshop vouchers, discounted parking permits and accident insurance. It runs clubs and societies vouchers. It runs free entry to guild shows. It runs a copy centre, a sports store and a tavern. It runs all these things that people like those opposite, the socialists in this chamber, said would collapse. They did not collapse.

Some of the credit for the introduction to Western Australia of the VSU, which was ultimately copied by the federal government because they could not improve on it, must go to the present Minister for Tourism and Mines, the Hon. Norman Moore, in the Legislative Council of Western Australia. He was assisted by Mark Dale, who is currently president of the national body of the Young Liberal movement in Australia, the Young Conservative movement. They put it together in 1994, and it is that system that the coalition government in the Commonwealth has decided to use, because it works; we know it works.

I do believe that one of the things that we can do for youth today, in particular youth in tertiary education stepping out into lifeâa quantum leap from secondary educationâis show them that democracy means the freedom to choose. I think it is a great indictment of universities and of previous governments that they did not allow students to choose when it was a formative area of their lives. What the coalition government is doing is giving students choice to join or not to join.

talk.start.para: âThe powers of a president as proposed for the republic deserve to be addressed more fully than they have been to date. The Constitution of this country is high law. It is the highest law we have and the people who decide on it are the High Court. There are many powers that reside with the monarch which have not yet been tested in the High Court. And there are those who believe that convention can overtake the law which is extant in our Constitution. I think that is an untested proposition.

speech.para: I want to address in this speech the so far rarely debated question of the proper powers that will attach to the office of the Australian president, if there is to be one, under the bipartisan republican model. I further want to draw to the Senate's attention some of the contradictions of that model with reference to the theory and practice of the exercise of presidential power.

The existing Australian Constitution vests considerable express powers in the formal head of state, the monarchâthe Queen. Most of these are of little or no practical application today. One power that still has practical application, however, is that of the appointment and dismissal of the Governor-General. This power is very much alive. This power is exercised on the advice of the Australian Prime Minister. Notwithstanding such advice, however, the Queen retains by Constitutional Convention and practiceâin Bagehot's wordsâthe right to be consulted, the right to encourage and the right to warn. Thus, when the Prime Minister says `jump' in relation to his or her advice to the Queen with regard to appointment or dismissal, the Queen has every right to ask not how high but instead `Why?' and `Is this the best course of action?'

A brief look at recent political history is instructive over the potential role of the Queen. In 1975, for example, had then Prime Minister Whitlam sought the removal of Governor-General Kerr prior to Kerr's dismissal of the government, the Queen would have been under no obligation in law to act without delay. This could potentially have given Kerr the necessary time to remove the government before the Queen acted on Whitlam's advice. Subsequent claims by some commentators that Prime Minister Whitlam was simply not quick enough to phone are therefore clearly erroneous. Such action by the Queen as our head of state, based on convention, would not be justiciable. The Prime Minister, in other words, was and currently is hampered in simply getting in first to dismiss the Governor-General in a similar constitutional crisis. The Queen does have power.

This admittedly odd structural arrangement has the advantage of providing a safety net, albeit an autocratic one, in allowing the removal of a government that, for example, wasâin the opinion of the Governor-Generalâacting in the most serious manner against the national interest. This arrangement gives the Governor-General breathing space to exercise a reserve power without the danger of being dismissed beforehand.

Consider a situation where a Prime Minister had lost the confidence of the lower house but where another member could command such confidence. But the Prime Minister, in an effort to prevent the other side of politics from gaining power, goes to the Governor-General advising a dissolution under section 5 of the Constitution. In such a situation, it is imperative that the Governor-General have the power to refuse such a dissolution and instead appoint the alternative government. Thus the current mechanism whereby the Governor-General can contemplate the exercise of reserve powers without fear of instant dismissal is a mechanism that must be retained, although obviously not in its now autocratic form. The parliament should therefore give serious consideration to the provision of such a safety net for the proposed president.

The government's exposure draft for the republic, however, would increase executive power by destroying this safety net. It does this by enabling the Prime Minister to dismiss the president without delay, thus stripping the president of the capacity to exercise his/her reserve powers first. That is clearly a shift in power from the monarch and the Governor-General to the Prime Minister. These reserve powers, as carried across from our present constitutional arrangements, are those that are thought to be exercisable under certain conditions at the Governor-General's own discretion. Four are usually cited as falling within this category: one, the power to appoint the Prime Minister; two, the power to dismiss the Prime Minister and therefore the government; three, the power to refuse to dissolve the House of Representatives under section 5 or both houses under section 57; and, four, the power to force a dissolution of the House of Representatives.

But under the exposure draft, the Prime Minister can simply pre-empt the proper presidential exercise of a reserve power. Where a Prime Minister had lost the confidence of the lower house, the Prime Ministerârushing to the phoneâcould dismiss the president instantly and prevent the appointment of an alternative government. This would throw our system of government into disarray. In effect, the reserve powers would become of historical interest only. In a scenario where the government was acting to the serious detriment of the nation, Australia would be plunged into a constitutional crisis with more grave implications than 1975.

Some might think that the scenarios I have portrayed are far-fetched in such a supposedly stable system of government as ours. But to those people I say: who could have predicted the events of 1975? Senators must understand that the integrity of constitutional structures are put to the test not in everyday affairs, but in precisely the sorts of crises that I have adverted to.

It is in these extreme situations that we find out whether our founding document has what it takes to protect our system of government from the unscrupulous and the power hungry. That is why I so persistently and consistently rail against the creation of what is an executive republic, against the moving of powers from the monarch and the Governor-General to the Prime Minister. The government's model must therefore be modified to allow a proper role for the exercise of presidential reserve powers. The most meritorious option to achieve this is to require that, in any case where the Prime Minister wishes to dismiss the president or where the president wishes to exercise a reserve power by acting against the advice of the Executive Council, the action be first ratified by a majority of each house of the federal parliament sitting separately.

This would have the considerable benefit of, firstly, giving to the parliamentâwhich is the elected representative body of the Australian peopleâthe power to confirm or deny the propriety of the proposed action. Secondly, it would ensure that, even under the bipartisan republican model, Australia would take on more of the character of a parliamentary republic, as opposed to the proposed executive republic. Thirdly, it would go some way toward diluting the inordinate power proposed to be given to just two office holders in our system of government and instead would distribute it more evenly within this system. That is, parliament would gain a sovereign position not only as the elected body of the populace but, importantly and properly, as a directing hand in times of constitutional conflict.

It is my opinion that the senators and parliamentarians give up their duty to the Australian people if they accept the executive republic which is being proposed to us at present. I think it is a perfectly legitimate view to take that some would prefer a parliamentary republic to a directly elected, popular republic. I can understand that difference. But to allow a change of our system which would increase the power of the executive and put at risk the sovereign rights of the people and the protections within our existing system is very dangerous for our society and needs to be resisted. It is for that reason that I raise the issues of the actual powers of the monarch, particularly with regard to appointment and dismissal of the Governor-General.

talk.start.para: âAs we sit here tonight, half a world away the Balkans is again aflame. Honourable senators would be aware from news coverage that horrific acts of brutality are now taking place in the area of Kosovo. The BBC reports that, for example, 60,000 refugees had streamed from Kosovo into Albania since Saturday. The British Foreign Secretary said this evening that refugees are being herded into concentration areas and that a sterile zone 10 kilometres wide has been established inside the borders of Kosovo. Elsewhere there are other frightening reports.

speech.para: NATO itself believes that as many as half a million people out of a population of two million are displaced. There are reports of 20,000 people in the town of Drenica being crowded onto trucks and taken away to unknown destinations. In Montenegro, refugees arriving in the city of Pec say that young men are being rounded up and taken away and that atrocities are occurring on a daily basis.

How, at the end of the 20th century, could this nightmare be repeated in Europe? The reason this nightmare is being repeated in Europe is that a massive miscalculation was made by President Clinton and others in NATOâa miscalculation on a scale which will leave unutterable terror for many people. The miscalculation was simply this: NATO and President Clinton believed that a war could be waged by air power alone and that a war would be waged without sending troops onto the ground.

On 25 March, President Clinton said that troops would not be necessary to ensure security in Kosovo, a claim he repeated yesterday. Yet, immediately the international observers left and the air strikes began, the real need for troops on the ground became apparentâbecause it is very clear that Serb forces have now taken this opportunity to round up their ethnic enemies and commit acts of atrocity and barbarity upon them. This happened because a fatal mistake was made. It happened because NATO, in their arrogance, thought that they could fight a war and not shed any of their own blood. The tragic consequence is that it is the blood of innocent people that is being shed at this very moment.

There are now frightening reports that a group of Serbian paramilitaries active in Bosniaâa group called the Tigers and led by a man known as Arkanâare once again waging the policy of ethnic cleansing, this time in Kosovo. And all without anybody to save these innocent people; all without even a person to observe the atrocities that are being committed. But we do not need to see the innocents executed to know that a monstrous evil, on a scale not seen since the long night of Nazi tyranny in Europe, is once again at hand.

The mistake having been made, the question is: how do we rectify it? The great dilemma now facing NATO and the Western world is surely that to stop the air war now would mean that Milosevic and the people like him who wish to wage ethnic war will have won, their capacity to continue to commit atrocities will be unblunted. But to blunder on, without clear plans, will inevitably meanâbarring some fortuitous circumstance in betweenâthat troops in Western Europe will be inexorably sucked into an abyss of ill-planned involvement, sucked into involvement without any clear objectives.

The danger this poses to the security of the Western world is this: if there are no clear objectives and troops get committed to the ground, then there is no way of containing the war, and containment of this conflict is absolutely critical. I remind honourable senators that 80 years ago a failure to contain a similar conflict in this very area of the world precipitated the First World War. It is incumbent upon the wise heads of the Western world to now formulate a plan as to how this conflict will be brought to an end. But it must be brought to an end in a way which ensures the safety and security of people who, but a couple of weeks ago, were living in their own homes. It must be brought about in a way in which there will be security, safety, and some chance of real life for those displaced people.

It is not an easy task and we must remember that peace was never won through temerity. Yet the West seems to be involved at the moment in a plan of cringing reluctance to pursue objectives with the conviction needed to succeed. In short, the West has embarked upon a very dangerous course of conduct indeed. The reason I stand here tonight is that I believe it is incumbent upon those of us who are in a position to lend some moral guidanceâalbeit from afarâto do so. We cannot stand by, now that this situation has been precipitated, and do nothing. We must urge the formulation of a plan to end the conflict.

I conclude with the simple thought that right now the very moral fabric of the Western world stands adjudged. If the Western world lacks a commitment to deal with this matter decisively, then I fear that history will be a very harsh judge indeed.

talk.start.para: âI rise again tonight to speak on the issue of electromagnetic radiation. The subject has not received much attention here in Australia of late, even though right now Standards Australia through its TE7 committee is considering relaxing the current standardâa matter I will return to a little later. There is however a great deal of action overseas. According to the World Health Organisation report, this is one of the four most important global issues.

speech.para: British and European parliaments are currently debating whether or not there is enough evidence to support prudent avoidance principles and policies. The sitings of cellphone towers in many countries in Europe, in the US, South Africa and South America continue to be flashpoints for community anger and frustration.

The Italian health minister is expected to call for a prudent avoidance policy when the European Union meets again in June, and the EU has called for the labelling of mobile phones as potential health hazards. In the UK, parliamentarians have criticised the government's telecommunications legislation as being too much `weighted in favour of industry and not of the environment'. Labour and Liberal Democrat members have said that the government would be `foolish to rule out the possibility of a health risk from radio frequency-microwave radiation'.

In Austria late last year, 16 of the top scientists in the area signed the Vienna Declaration, which recognises that low intensity microwaves can cause biological effects or damage to humans. In Salzburg, the public health department has adopted an interim public exposure standard based on a study that showed adverse health effects from mobile phones on sleeping subjects. They have consequently introduced a standard that is 2,000 times stricter than the Australian one.

A South African mobile phone company has been the first in the world to offer its 112,000 staff a free radiation shield. And in that country, a long-term mobile user who has a brain tumour is bringing legal action against the industry. In England, a legal firm is acting on behalf of 24 brain tumour victims.

In the US, a number of community groups, including the Communications Workers of America, supported by 22 doctors, have filed a suit against the Federal Communications Commission alleging that the guidelines fail to protect public health and the environment from harm.

In Sweden, the Union of Clerical and Technical Employees in Industry organisation has published a new booklet entitled Hypersensitive in IT Environments to advise their work force on how to deal with emerging problems of electroradiation. A recent British study shows that mobile phone radiation stimulates a morphine-like chemical in the brain. As cancer is recognised as being triggered by endocrine system imbalances, the long-term ramifications of these results might be considerable.

It has come to my attention that birds too are affected by electromagnetic radiation. In the US recently, thousands of homing pigeons have been lost, with pigeon racing clubs claiming mobile phone infrastructure as the cause. The Washington Post reported last October that, of the 1,800 birds competing in a 200-mile race, 1,500 failed to return. In another race, 700 out of 900 went missing. In a 350-mile race, the number lost was 1,000 out of 1,200.

Clubs are saying that such losses are extraordinary, but have been on the increase over the past few years. Ireland has also recently reported similar occurrences quoting pigeon club authorities as saying that the problem of lost birds has worsened as satellite television and mobile communications networks in the state have developed. New Zealand has had similar problems.

In the US, organisations are also saying that wild geese no longer fly in their characteristic V-formation and, back home, members of the Victorian Homing Association have told my office that the 700-mile race to Queensland has experienced unexplained losses in recent years. They have also noticed that birds are more likely to be lost if they fly through areas where there are significant numbers of mobile phone towers as opposed to flying across the desert.

As senators will be aware, birds navigate by means of magnetic particles in the brain, so it stands to reason that they will be vulnerable to the changes in electromagnetic environments. The implications are not just serious for pigeon fanciers; presumably, migratory birds are also having difficulty with navigation. It is quite possible that preserving important wetlands, through the Ramsar convention, is not going to be enough to protect these migratory water birds.

You would expect the federal government to be interested in these phenomena, and I hope we do not get the usual dismissive jokes from Senator Alston about mice or, in this case, birds and mobile phones, because the wireless communications industry is moving very quickly to flood the air spaces with low level microwaves and flood the market with equipment which exceeds current Australian standards.

As we found out last year, the Australian Communications Authority does not have the capacity to check mobile phones for compliance with our standards and certainly no-one is going around testing mobile phone tower emissions. Nevertheless, all of our mobile phones are made overseas and there is a push to relax the standards so that we can have uniform worldwide compliance and, therefore, no need for us to be embarrassed about our inability to insist on compliance.

As Stewart Fist commented in the Australian two weeks ago, our standards have little to do with anything but heat emissions in any case and they fail to recognise radio frequency microwave radiation emissions as having any biological effects. You could argue that a standard which is anyway measuring the wrong thing is not worth fighting to retain. The CSIRO argues strongly that it is, because at least there is some brake on the energy that can be put to your brain. As I see more and more executives talking into microphones dangling under their chin, with their mobile phone held at a distance, I think we all know that there is more to fear than a phone warming up your cheekbone.

For the past couple of months, government and the industry have been trying very hard to relax Australia's radio frequency microwave public exposure standard. Standards Australia informed its TE7 committee just last week that it would upgrade the standard. The committee has struck a bit of bother because the community reps on the committee, the unions and the CSIRO cannot be persuaded by industry to support the move. In spite of the fact that the committee is stacked with industry and government, they need an 80 per cent vote in favour to adopt a new standard, which they did not get when the question was put to the vote.

The ACA has intervened and last week threatened these reluctant members that it would be obliged to step in by mid-April, saying that its preferred option is the adoption of the new standard. It argues that the old standard will shortly expire and that this is the only sensible course of action. I have commented in this place before tonight that there is no longer any justification for industry to dominate standard setting. We are not talking here about component parts like nuts and bolts being standardised so that they fit together. The many people who are experiencing effects from using mobile phones are worried not about whether the phone has standard features but whether it is slowly damaging their brain.

As it stands at the moment, the standard setting process in Australia for telecommunications is not precautionary and is not in the best interests of health, and most people know that. The ACA and the industry should not be allowed to relax our standards until they are able to convince our pre-eminent scientific body, the CSIRO, and ordinary citizens on the committee that it is the right thing to do.

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to talk about the death of a hero. Dr Michael Aris was a humanitarian academic, a Tibetan specialist and the husband of Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

speech.para: Dr Aris passed away on Saturday, 27 March. His illness was brought to international attention by the Burmese military regime's refusal to allow Dr Aris to visit Daw Suu Kyi in Burma before he became too seriously ill to travel. Dr Aris had been applying for a visa for the past three years, even when he was not aware of his illness. In recent months, however, the requests became urgent. Even when he was ill, he did not pressure Daw Suu Kyi to leave Burma to visit him in Oxford because he respected and supported the immense and unwavering responsibility which she has for her country and its people.

The story of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Dr Michael Aris is one of commitment, sacrifice, courage and love. They were married in 1972 and they have two children, Alexander and Kim, both now in their 20s, and both cut off from their mother for years because of the actions of the Burmese military regime. These young men cannot visit their mother in Burma because the military junta, the State Peace and Development Council, will not allow them to. Daw Suu Kyi will not leave Burma because the SPDC has made undertakings to her in the past about her freedom of movement but each time has reneged on its promises. The SPDC now tell Suu Kyi that she may leave Burma to attend her husband's funeral. She feels she cannot because she would not be allowed to return. In this, as in so many things, the SPDC cannot be trusted.

Dr Aris died on his 53rd birthday. It also happened to be the Myanmar National Army DayâTatmadaw Dayâa day when the army parades its strength, and did so with 6,000 troops taking to the streets in what has become an annual part of the military's intimidation tactics. Ironically, the day was originally called Resistance Day, and was meant to be a day of celebration for the Burmese people to celebrate the struggle of the Burmese people against Japanese occupation in World War Two. Now it serves to remind of the struggle of the Burmese people against another kind of occupationâthat of their own military junta.

The oppositionâthe National League for Democracyâof which Daw Suu Kyi is the leader issued a statement calling for unity and restoration of democracy in Burma. In doing so, they are also pleading for the support of the international community for their causeâthe protection of human rights and the restoration of democracy.

The military was also condemned by the national coalition government of the Union of Burma, which comprises members of parliament who were driven into exile after the military refused to honour the result of the 1990 national election which Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy won in a landslide victory. Australia is now home to several of those exiled members of parliament.

We take our democracy so much for granted in this country that we just cannot conceive of what it must be like to actually win government and never be allowed to govern. More than that, just because you are a member of the political party successful in an election, you are subject to torture, imprisonment, arbitrary detention and persecution.

Daw Suu Kyi enjoys overwhelming support from the Burmese people, and from the international community. She lives a restricted life of virtual house arrest and has done for many years. The military have used many strategies to attempt to force her to give up her struggle. Through all this, and for the whole of their life together, Michael Aris was unfailingly understanding and supportive of her.

International human rights groups, the President of the United States and the United Nations Secretary-General have all condemned the military's decision not to grant a visa to Dr Aris to enable him and his sons to visit Suu Kyi. I am concerned, however, that the Australian government seems to be wavering in its resolve to support Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the properly elected government of Burma.

It concerns me that the minister recently criticised the European Union for maintaining the policy prohibiting visits by Burmese military ministers and also that Australia broke ranks with other Western nations by attending a controversial narcotics conference held in Rangoon at ambassadorial level, not just at the law enforcement level, as originally offered as justification. I hope that the government is not weakening Australia's position on Burma. I believe now is the time for it to clarify that policy.

Dr Aris last saw his wife in January 1996. After that, the Burmese SPDC repeatedly denied him a visa, even when they knew he was dying. He was reported to have been willing to die in Rangoon, if he could just have seen his beloved Suu one more time. It is too late now for a husband and wife to be united, but it is not too late for a mother to be reunited with her sons. The SPDC should, of course, immediately grant visas to Alexander and Kim Aris to visit their mother at this most tragic time for their family.
Michael was one of a group of distinguished scholars who focused on the humanitarian aspects of Buddhism and the history of

parts of South Asia. He was the gentle scholar and she was the political activist. His great love for his wife drew him into the role of her spokesman, and an unwavering supporter of the rights of the Burmese people.

The situation in Burma is just as awful as that in Serbia. Australia must look closely at our own actions in relation to Burma, and our own failure to influence change there. We send our condolences to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her two sons, Alexander and Kim, and we hope that the SPDC can be prevailed upon to at least allow them to be together at this very sad time.
